intro: Pedicularis przewalskii var. hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy lousewort, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Orobanchaceae, which includes many parasitic and hemiparasitic species. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, which help it retain moisture in its arid habitat. Its flowers are typically reddish or purple, with a distinctive two-lipped structure that attracts pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It is often found growing in rocky or alpine environments at high elevations.
